title: 105_hr3679
content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. The United States Customs Service and Immigration and Naturalization Service are authorized appropriations for enhancing border investigative resources, anticorruption efforts, and combating drug smuggling and money-laundering. This includes funding for salaries, expenses, and equipment for these purposes. The United States Customs Service and Immigration and Naturalization Service are authorized appropriations to enhance investigative resources for anticorruption efforts, combat drug smuggling and money-laundering, and reduce traffic waiting times at major land border ports of entry. Appropriations include specific amounts for fiscal years 1999 and 2000, with additional funding as necessary in subsequent years. Specifically, $48,404,000 is allocated for acquisition and other expenses for the Customs Service in fiscal year 1999. The United States Customs Service is allocated $48,404,000 for acquisition and expenses related to narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes funding for Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems, mobile truck x-rays, fixed-site truck x-ray upgrades, pallet x-rays, portable contraband detectors, and contraband detection kits. The United States Customs Service is allocated funds for various contraband detection equipment along the Southwest border, including ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, and weigh-in-motion sensors. The United States Customs Service is allocated funds for various contraband detection equipment along the Southwest border, including ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, weigh-in-motion sensors, AM radio stations, inbound vehicle counters, spotter camera systems, inbound commercial truck transponders, narcotics detectors, and license plate reader automatic systems. The Immigration and Naturalization Service is allocated $15,090,000 for narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest land border, including mobile truck x-rays, ultrasonic container inspection units, and Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals. The funding allocation for border patrol checkpoints includes $240,000 for 10 TECS terminals, $1,000,000 for 20 surveillance camera systems, $175,000 for 35 AM radio stations, $875,000 for 35 spotter camera systems, and $1,600,000 for 40 narcotics detectors. Additionally, $4,840,400 is allocated for Customs Service technology in fiscal year 2000 and beyond. The funding allocation for Customs Service technology includes $4,840,400 for equipment maintenance and personnel training in fiscal year 2000 and beyond. The Commissioner of Customs has the flexibility to use the allocated funds for equipment other than specified in subsection (b)(1). The Commissioner of Customs has the authority to reallocate funds for technologically superior equipment that achieves the same results at a lower cost. The Attorney General oversees funding and equipment specified in subsection (b)(2). The Attorney General has the same authority as the Commissioner of Customs for specified amounts and equipment. $112,844,584 in fiscal year 1999 and $180,910,928 for fiscal year 2000 will be allocated for increased inspectors and resources at the Southwest and Northern borders to enhance investigative capabilities and process cargo efficiently. The allocation of funds for increased personnel and resources at cargo facilities, drug distribution centers, and internal affairs for anticorruption efforts is authorized. Additionally, funds are designated for hiring personnel in fiscal years 1999 and 2000. In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, funds are allocated for increased personnel and resources at the Southwest and Northern land borders, including additional inspectors, canine enforcement officers, vehicles, intelligence analysts, and resources for drug distribution centers. Increase in personnel and resources at drug distribution centers, transportation centers, and the Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Justice to enhance efforts against drug smuggling, money-laundering, and corruption.
